description: From Middle English better, bettre, betre, from Old English betera (“better”), from Proto-West Germanic *batiʀō, from Proto-Germanic *batizô (“better”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰed-rós, from *bʰed- (“good”).

Cognate with Sanskrit भद्र (bhadrá, “blessed, fortunate, happy, good”) (from *bʰn̥d-ró-s). For Germanic cognates: see Proto-Germanic *batizô. Related to best and battle (“getting better, improving, fruitful, fertile”). Compare also Icelandic batna (“to improve”), bót (“improvement”), German besser. More at batten, boot.
Persian بهتر‎ is a false cognate.

adjectives.description: better (positive good, adverb well, comparative (humorous) betterer, superlative (humorous) betterest, or (standard) best)

examples: “The air was still with the lonely thrill of 'now the hour is near'  And the smell of sweat was better yet than the awful stench of fear.”

entries.meaning: Greater or lesser (whichever is seen as more advantageous), in reference to value, distance, time, etc.
examples: The top electric vehicles have a range of 300 kilometres or better. (better = greater)
Only one swimmer finished the race with a time better than two minutes. (better = lesser)
The engine runs better now that I've given it some oil.
You better do that if you know what's good for you.

entries.meaning: An entity, usually animate, deemed superior to another; one who has a claim to precedence; a superior.
examples: He quickly found Ali his better in the ring.
It's getting late. You better get on home.

description: From Middle English beteren, from Old English beterian, betrian, from Proto-Germanic *batizōną. Cognate with West Frisian betterje (“to better”), Dutch beteren (“to better”), German bessern (“to better”), Danish bedre (“to better”), Swedish bättra (“to better”).

verbs.description: better (third-person singular simple present betters, present participle bettering, simple past and past participle bettered)

examples: This government will better this society

entries.meaning: (transitive) To surpass in excellence; to exceed; to excel.
examples: The works of nature do always aim at that which can not be bettered.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give advantage to; to support; to advance the interest of.

description: Alternate spelling of bettor or modern formation from the verb to bet.
